results.title: Hope
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Rowena Ashley and ACMI
results.brief_description: Whether in the city or a small town, Rowena Ashley’s son Michael has had to endure racism from a young age. This is a story about achieving against the odds. This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with Arts Victoria and the Community Support Fund.

results.title: Old man: new world
results.brief_description: The life of an Old Man is viewed unfolding before us, jumping like memory through time and through everyday spaces with the blinking quickness of an edit. From shot to shot and from screen to screen, a life re-editing itself. Through the ‘old’ eyes of the central character, we glimpse anew the details of our ordinary world and time.
results.description: The life of an Old Man is viewed unfolding before us, jumping like memory through time and through everyday spaces with the blinking quickness of an edit. results.title: Instrument
results.brief_description:
Jem Cohen is a New York-based producer working in 16mm and 8mm film and video. His poetic, often ephemeral, work is marked by a blurring of the distinctions between documentary, narrative, and experimental genres. Cohen frequently shoots in hundreds of locations without any additional crew, in the tradition of documentary street photographers such as Robert Frank. His projects include collaborations with poets, writers, and bands such as R.E.M. and Fugazi, creating alternatives to generic and commodified ‘music video.’
‘Instrument’ is a collaboration between Jem Cohen and the Washington DC band Fugazi, the project covers the ten year period from the bands inception in 1987. Far from a traditional documentary, the project is a musical document: a portrait of musicians at work.

results.title: Confession from the Commander's diary: a narration in five parts
results.creator_credit: Svetlana Voloshina, L. Semenova and Alexander Sokurov
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: Observing the rituals, gestures and trance-like states of his crew, a naval Commander ponders his life. How did he get here? What went wrong? And right? Will he ever know light again? Probing the dark, unspecified seas, the ship becomes contemporary Russia: dazzling midnight snowstorms; plain human actions shaped by centuries of weariness and wanting; persistence; inquiry.
results.title_for_label: Confession from the Commander’s diary: a narration in five parts
results.creator_credit_for_label: Svetlana Voloshina, L. Semenova and Alexander Sokurov

results.title: Visions of Victoria
results.creator_credit: Janne Martin Video Productions and Stewart Faichney
results.brief_description:
On a continent distinguished for its unique mixture of climates and for its exotic wildlife, there is no state that provides more variety and contrast than Victoria. Occupying the south-east corner of Australia, and only slightly larger than the size of Great Britain, Victoria has something for everybody. This video takes you on a remarkable tour of the state of Victoria which includes the wilderness areas of its world famous national parks, some of the best surf beaches in the world, Australia’s largest inland lagoon system, a rugged shipwrecked coast, winter resorts and high country, wetlands and even deserts. Also the vibrant and sophisticated city of Melbourne, renowned for its beautiful parks and gardens, exciting restaurants and nightlife, its devotion to the arts and, of course, a fanatical love of sports of all kinds. This superb video is a comprehensive celebration of this wonderful state, in all its beauty, seasons and moods.

Note: the end has a segment on film classification showing Bill Collins introducing the “G” rating.

results.title: Beautiful brown eyes
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, David Facey and ACMI
results.brief_description: When David Facey’s daughter was born the first thing he fell in love with was her beautiful brown eyes. Ironically, it was those same eyes that told him something wasn’t quite right.
